questions.stem: The reservoirs of infection for tetanus include:
questions.explanation: Tetanus spores are found in soil and in the intestines of animals (including humans), making all three components reservoirs of infection[cite: 321, 322, 323, 324, 325].

questions.stem: What measures are used for the specific prevention of tetanus after an injury?
questions.explanation: Comprehensive post-exposure prophylaxis for tetanus includes the tetanus toxoid vaccine for active immunity, tetanus immunoglobulin (seroprophylaxis) for passive immunity, and antibiotics (chemoprophylaxis) for wound management[cite: 326, 327, 328, 329, 330].

questions.stem: Which of the following is true about specific prevention for Hepatitis C?
options: Combined seroprophylaxis and vaccination is used.
No effective specific preventive measure is available.
questions.explanation: Currently, there is no vaccine or effective seroprophylaxis available for the prevention of Hepatitis C infection[cite: 339, 340, 341, 342, 343].

questions.stem: For specific prevention of rabies after a severe exposure, what is the recommended protocol?
options: Seroprophylaxis should be given with chemoprophylaxis.
Seroprophylaxis should be given with the vaccine.
questions.explanation: Post-exposure prophylaxis for a severe rabies exposure involves immediate administration of both the rabies vaccine to stimulate an active immune response and rabies immunoglobulin (seroprophylaxis) for immediate passive protection[cite: 349, 350, 351, 352, 353].

questions.stem: Which of the following is NOT a mode of transmission for HIV/AIDS?
questions.explanation: HIV is transmitted through sexual contact, blood, and from mother to child (vertically). [cite_start]It is not transmitted by vectors like mosquitoes or ticks[cite: 363, 364, 365, 366, 367].

questions.stem: The reservoir of infection for HIV/AIDS includes:
options: Man: cases and all types of carriers
questions.explanation: Humans are the only reservoir for HIV. [cite_start]An infected person, whether they are an acute case or an asymptomatic carrier (incubatory, convalescent, or healthy), can transmit the virus[cite: 374, 375, 376, 377, 378].

questions.stem: What is the protective value of the Hepatitis B vaccine?
options: It gives protective neutralizing antibodies in about 96% of recipients.
It gives protective neutralizing antibodies in about 80% of recipients.
It gives protective neutralizing antibodies in about 67% of recipients.
It gives protective neutralizing antibodies in about 50% of recipients.
questions.explanation: The Hepatitis B vaccine is highly effective, inducing a protective antibody response in approximately 96% of healthy individuals who complete the series[cite: 389, 390, 391].

questions.stem: Tetanus toxoid induces immunity that persists for at least 10 years after full immunization.
questions.explanation: True. [cite_start]A full primary series of the tetanus toxoid vaccine provides protection for at least 10 years, with boosters recommended every 10 years to maintain immunity[cite: 394].

questions.stem: Routine social contact with HIV-infected persons, such as coughing, sneezing, and working with them, carries a risk of transmission.
questions.explanation: False. HIV is not transmitted through casual or social contact. [cite_start]The virus does not spread through air, water, or surfaces[cite: 394].

questions.stem: Egypt has the highest prevalence of HCV in the world, with about 10% of its population being chronically infected.
questions.explanation: True. [cite_start]Egypt has historically had one of the highest burdens of Hepatitis C virus (HCV) worldwide, largely due to past iatrogenic transmission[cite: 394].

questions.stem: The yeast-recombinant Hepatitis B vaccine has replaced the plasma-derived vaccine for mass vaccination at present.
questions.explanation: True. [cite_start]Due to safety and production advantages, genetically engineered yeast-recombinant vaccines are now the standard for Hepatitis B immunization, having replaced the older vaccines derived from the plasma of chronic carriers[cite: 394].
